But though he 'expressly disclaimed any wish to impose his own opinions on his contemporaries or successors (aelel altit praeeo quad sequantur), the authority of his great name sufficed to induce a general suspension ofjudgement during the two centuries which succeeded his epoch. Some scholars adhered to the Tacitean tradition, others advocated Quintilian²: some took a new departure, ascribing the Dzalagae to the younger Pliny, orto Suetonius or to the poet-pleader who is its central figure, Curiatius Maternus.
